race.name: Homegrown Gravel Adventure
race.tagline: Rolling Georgia gravel in rural west Georgia.

climate.description: Variable conditions with heat possible in spring, cool possible in fall, and humidity.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through rolling west Georgia. Moderate elevation with rural scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional Georgia event. Rolling terrain is moderate but rural location and limited organization.

biased_opinion.summary: Homegrown Gravel Adventure is a regional event in rural Franklin, west Georgia. The rolling terrain offers moderate climbing with rural scenery, but the rural location, limited amenities, and moderate organization keep it firmly in Tier 3. Franklin is a small town with limited lodging and dining. It's a solid regional event for Georgia cyclists.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid regional Georgia gravel race with rolling terrain. Worth it for Georgia cyclists seeking a local event. Not a destination race for out-of-state travelers.

final_verdict.one_liner: Rural rolling Georgia gravel in west Georgia.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in Georgia and want a local rolling gravel event—yes, it's a solid regional race. If you're from out of state—there are better options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Southeast events: Gravel Worlds, Pisgah Monster-Cross, Hot Springs Gravel Gauntlet. For similar regional events: other Georgia gravel races.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Franklin has limited lodging. LaGrange or Newnan have more options.
logistics.food: Small town with limited dining. Stock nutrition.
logistics.parking: parking at high school is "pretty far from the start/finish, and at the top of a hill
logistics.camping: Camping options:** On-site camping available at Riverside Park (primitive camping and RV spaces with no electricity/water hookup

course_description.character: Rolling Georgia gravel with moderate climbing.
course_description.signature_challenge: Rolling Georgia gravel in rural west Georgia.

non_negotiables.why: Rolling Georgia terrain requires sustained effort.
Georgia spring/fall means heat and humidity are possible.
Rural location requires self-sufficiency and preparation.

topics.heat: Racing in Georgia heat and humidity

marketplace_variables.race_hook: Rolling Georgia gravel in rural west Georgia.

logistics.explanation: Michael Garrison drove to Atlanta and back on race morning after forgetting his nutrition pack, highlighting Franklin's limited last-minute options. The course isn't marked, requiring GPS navigation as Molly Hurford warns: "make sure you have the route loaded to your cycling computer or phone." A week before 2024, bridge washouts forced major route changes.

length.explanation: The 100-mile option delivers 8,700 feet of climbing across Georgia and Alabama. Jason Lopez called his effort "quite pleased with my race performance" despite 7,500 feet of climbing over nearly six hours. Four distance options from 20 to 100 miles let riders pick their suffering level appropriately. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: The course features a 23% grade section and "gravel with random chunks that could cause a pinch flat if hit wrong" according to Jason Lopez. Creek crossings and sketchy bridge crossings add complexity, while sand sections "can definitely catch you out" per rider warnings. Technical descents lack Strava segments because they're too gnarly to map. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: 8,700 feet over 100 miles creates sustained climbing across two states, with the course featuring "quite a bit of climbing" and fast technical descents per Jason Lopez. Elite men's racing stayed controlled early with "riders mindful of the grueling course ahead" before splintering by mile 30. The climbing is relentless but not Alpine-severe. Less climbing than The Mid South.

climate.explanation: February temperatures plunged to mid-20s°F at start, climbing to 50s°F by day in 2025 after seven inches of rain the previous week. Jason Lopez noted the 38°F to 60°F swing "made it a bit tough to dress for." One rider emphasized: "Be prepared for ANY weather" including full winter conditions. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Georgia piedmont terrain means sea-level elevation with zero impact on racing. The 8,700 feet referenced is elevation gain, not altitude above sea level. Andrew L'Esperance came straight from Quebec's eight feet of snow to perfect breathing conditions in Franklin's rolling hills. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Jason Lopez described "riding through some of the little rural towns, isolated forested sections, and pasture areas" with water crossings where "your feet will almost certainly get wet." The Georgia-Alabama border crossing delivers authentic Southern gravel through secluded terrain, but this isn't wilderness expedition territory.

prestige.explanation: Lauren De Crescenzo, Michael Garrison, Ian Boswell, and Andrew L'Esperance headlined recent editions with a $10,000 prize purse drawing elite talent. Ian Boswell called it "the best event that I will do all year" for its racing style and atmosphere. The pro field presence elevates a small-town event into something noteworthy.

race_quality.explanation: Race promoter Wayne Whiteside called his route "quite possibly the best route I have ever created." Lauren De Crescenzo praised the "hero dirt—fast, tacky gravel with just a few muddy spots and creek crossings. Pretty much perfect." Course organization struggles with neutral starts that immediately blow up and unmarked navigation.

experience.explanation: Lauren De Crescenzo described perfect hero dirt conditions while Ian Boswell found "a sense of camaraderie with everyone" and mutual respect among competitors. Custom finisher beanies, homecooked food from East Point Track Club, and downtown Franklin takeover create memorable post-race atmosphere. The festival element transforms the small town completely.

community.explanation: Ian Boswell captured the vibe: "It's competitive, but there are no people standing on the start line 45 minutes before trying to get up front. There was a neutral section through the mud and everyone just waited for each other." Proceeds support MTB Atlanta and Heard County Food Pantry with $2,000 in donations.

field_depth.explanation: 524 registered riders from 17 states in 2025 with 25 women in the elite field. The $10,000 prize purse attracts heavy hitters like De Crescenzo and Garrison annually. Andrew L'Esperance made this only his second outdoor ride of 2025, showing it draws talent for early-season fitness testing despite the remote location. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100. As Jason Lopez puts it: "I am quite pleased with my race performance in the 2024 Border Wars Gravel, I finished 11th in my category, even with 7500 ft of climbing. My average speed was 16."

value.explanation: Custom hand-made trophies, finisher beanies, homecooked food, beer, and major raffle prizes including Wahoo Kickr and custom Eliel clothing deliver exceptional value. One rider noted "huge effort into the festival element, tons of post-ride food and beverage" with the $10,000 pro purse elevating the entire field experience.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $60-100. Franklin offers one great Mexican restaurant (Del Rio with "massive margaritas"), free public restrooms by the police station, and small-town pricing. Community park camping keeps costs minimal while being one hour from Atlanta's airport. The downtown takeover atmosphere comes without destination race pricing premiums. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

quotes.text: The race broke up super early it was at Mile like 15 or 20 that the Breakaway formed and it was something like 27° fahrenheit when we started and so a lot of guys still wearing you know like leg warmers or full-length tights got a lot of different layers on.

I like races without a lot of climbing and this was the one for me so pretty much spent the whole middle of the race riding with three guys and then started to pick it up towards the end cuz I got kind of tired of toodling around.

key_challenges.name: Early breakaway formation
key_challenges.description: The race broke up super early with a breakaway forming at mile 15-20, making it crucial to be positioned well from the start.

key_challenges.name: Bottleneck section
key_challenges.description: There's a bottleneck area that can cause riders to dangle off the peloton if not positioned properly.

terrain_notes.text: The course is mostly gravel roads with some chunky, gnarly stuff on descents where you need both hands on the bars. Riders describe typical Alabama and Georgia gravel roads.
Mixed surface riding with paved sections interspersed throughout the gravel sections.

race_day_tips.text: Be prepared for cold starts - it was 27 degrees Fahrenheit at race start, so layering with leg warmers or full-length tights is important.
Position yourself well early as the race breaks up around mile 15-20 and you don't want to get caught behind the bottleneck.

additional_quotes.text: This event is hosted by longstanding cycling promoter Mr Wayne Whitesides and takes riders from Georgia crossing the border into Alabama and back again.
I like races without a lot of climbing and this was the one for me.

rider_intel.search_text: Homegrown Gravel Adventure in Franklin, Georgia is a mixed-surface race hosted by Wayne Whitesides that takes riders from Georgia into Alabama and back. The 100-mile course is mostly gravel roads with some paved sections, featuring chunky and gnarly descents typical of Alabama and Georgia terrain. The race starts cold with temperatures around 27 degrees Fahrenheit, requiring proper layering. A key challenge occurs early when the race breaks up around mile 15-20 with breakaway formation, and there's a bottleneck section that can separate riders from the main group. Riders describe it as having minimal climbing, making it appealing for those who prefer flatter gravel courses. The event offers multiple distance options including 62-mile and 100-mile routes, with the longer distance crossing state borders for added adventure.
